The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Laboratory as a site and how it can be used as a site of analysis to reflect contemporary scientific discourse and practices.
A lot of voicing articulate opinions and thoughts in class discussion; a really interesting topic that I never thought to dive into before

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: interesting readings, well rounded syllabus, engaged professor. Weaknesses: poorly engaged students. Even though we had to submit weekly reading questions, it was clear that not everyone did the readings, which really hampers discussion in a small class. Not the professors fault though, I would say. But discussion was lackluster and disappointing considering the interesting material. Exacerbated by the small class size.

Great readings, great topics, great field trips-- more background needed for this class though in terms of history of science, which I did not have, which makes the class more fun and exciting but it might help for class discussion

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, but shop it and make sure you like the other people and the professor.

Yes, I would recommend this course 100%! You learn so much about the history and development of laboratory spaces; if you're a science major or have any interest in learning about the subject with fascinating readings and interesting class discussions, this is the class for you.
Yes I would-- even for STEM students that want to know more about the origins of their workspace, the topics are really interesting and fascinating
